title-group.article-title: Synthesis and Electrochemistry of Copper(I) Complexes with Weakly Basic, Fluorinated, and Multicyclic Arenes

aff.named-content: Institut für Anorganische und Analytische Chemie und Freiburger Materialforschungszentrum (FMF)

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). Chemistry – A European Journal published by Wiley‐VCH GmbH

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The dinitrogen complex [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] (RF = C(CF3)3) acts as the precursor for the synthesis of homoleptic, weakly bound Cu(I)‐arene complexes with benzene, fluorinated, and multicyclic arenes. Upon dissolution of [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] in benzene or the fluorinated arenes xFB (x = number of fluorine atoms, x = 1−4), the complexes [Cu(C6H6)2−3]+[Al(ORF)4]−, [Cu(xFB)2−3]+[Al(ORF)4]− (x = 1−3), or the ion pair [(xFB)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] (x = 4) form. Both the benzene and fluorobenzene complexes are also available in larger scales by oxidation of elemental copper in the respective solvents using [NO]+[Al(ORF)4]− as an oxidant. A higher degree of fluorination of the arene ligand leads to a weaker coordination of the Cu(I) atom and thus to higher Cu+/Cu redox potentials in solution that reach an unprecedentedly high value of +1.5 V (!) versus the ferrocenium/ferrocene couple in pentafluorobenzene. The versatile applicability of [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] as a “naked” Cu(I) source is demonstrated by complexation reactions with the multicyclic arenes anthracene and hexaphenylbenzene that yielded multiply charged cations. All complexes presented in this work were characterized by their single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction structures.

Weak Coordination, High Potentials: Making use of the weakly coordinated copper(I)‐dinitrogen complex [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] (RF = C(CF3)3) as a precursor, homoleptic Cu(I)‐arene complexes with weakly basic (fluorinated) arene ligands were synthesized. The higher the degree of fluorination of the arenes, the weaker are their interaction with Cu(I) and the higher are their Cu+/Cu redox potentials reaching +1.5 V versus Fc+/Fc in pentafluorobenzene.

award-group.funding-source: State of Baden‐Württemberg: bwHPC Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft

sec.title: Introduction
Syntheses of the Cu(I)‐Arene Complexes and NMR‐Spectroscopy
Structures and Energetics of the Cu(I)‐xFB Complexes from [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)4}]
sec.p: Depending on the reaction and crystallization conditions, crystals of either the tris‐benzene complex [Cu(C6H6)3]+[Al(ORF)4]− 1 or less stable crystals of the bis‐benzene complex [Cu(C6H6)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− 2 can be obtained from [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)4}]: Addition of only two equivalents of C6H6 and layering with n‐heptane favors the formation of 2. However, when C6H6 is used in excess as solvent and no antisolvent is added, exclusively 1 crystallizes. Similarly, both the copper tris‐fluorobenzene complex [Cu(1FB)3]+[Al(ORF)4]− 3 and the less stable bis‐fluorobenzene complex [Cu(1FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− 4 are accessible depending on which crystallization method is chosen. In addition, 2 and 4 can be selectively obtained from 1 and 3 by (re‐)crystallization using the layering method with hydrocarbons. From 3FB solution, the salt structure of [Cu(3FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− 5 crystallizes. Yet, in very weakly coordinating 4FB, the contact ion pair [(4FB)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] 6 forms, in which the anion serves as an auxiliary ligand. Note that, while the tris‐arene complexes only slowly decompose when brought to open air, the bis‐arene complexes quickly decompose, and the contact ion 6 requires low temperatures (−20 °C) for handling (Supporting Information, Section 3).

caption.p: Molecular structures of the cationic moieties of [Cu(C6H6)3]+[Al(ORF)4]− 1 (Pna21, R 1 = 7.8%, wR 2 = 24.5%, measured at 200 K), [Cu(C6H6)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− 2 (P 1¯, R 1 = 9.0%, wR 2 = 27.7%), [Cu(1FB)3]+[Al(ORF)4]− 3 (Pna21, R 1 = 6.5%, wR 2 = 18.2%, measured at 200 K), [Cu(1FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− 4 (P 1¯, R 1 = 8.0%, wR 2 = 24.2%), [Cu(3FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− 5 (P21/c, R 1 = 4.2%, wR 2 = 9.8%) and crystal structure of the ion‐pair [(4FB)Cu{Al(ORF)4}] 6 (modification 6a: P21/n, R 1 = 10.7%, wR 2 = 26.5%, modification 6b: Cc, R 1 = 5.5%, wR 2 = 13.5%). Disorders omitted for clarity (for complete structures see Supporting Information, Section 6). Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level. Selected bond lengths are given where appropriate (the crystallographic data for 4 do not allow for a discussion of coordinative motives or bond lengths, see Supporting Information, Section 6). For 6, bond lengths for modification 6a are given due to the better C─C bond precision (despite the overall higher R 1 value for 6a). Yet, the bond lengths in 6b are identical inside the error margins to 6a.

fn.p: Solvation Gibbs energies computed for the corresponding solvent xFB using the CPCM‐model and at the RI‐r2SCAN‐3c(D4)/def2‐mTZVPP level of theory.

Energies computed in the gas phase due to long computational times for the large anion. As only neutral compounds are involved, solvation energies are comparatively small and similar for all compounds and thus negligible.

sec.p: Note that the isodesmically calculated exchange energies of the silver‐arene‐complexes with the Cu+ ion described in Table 1 (entries II and III) are needed to rationalize the CV‐measured formal potentials in one of the next sections and are described and utilized there.

sec.title: Formal Potentials of the Cu(I)‐xFB Complexes versus Ferrocene

fn.p: The Cu+ potential is not stable over the scan rates but increases with increasing scan rate in the weakly polar solvent 5FB. Still, the potential is higher than 1.5 V for all measured scan rates between 20 and 1000 mV s−1.

sec.title: Comparison to Calculated Energetics
sec.p: To prove this point, quantum chemical calculations were conducted to quantify the strengths of Cu+‐arene interactions in comparison to the Ag+‐arene interactions (Table 1, entries II and III). Hence, the Gibbs free energies of the isodesmic ligand exchange between Cu+‐ and Ag+‐arene complexes were computed at the RI‐r2SCAN‐3c(D4)/def2‐mTZVPP level of density functional theory (DFT). For 1FB, the tris‐arene complexes were regarded, for 2FB and 3FB the bis‐arene complexes and for 4FB the ion‐pairs with one coordinated 4FB arene. In the homoleptic salt structures, the Cu+‐arene interactions are indeed stronger than the Ag+‐arene interactions by approximately 40 kJ mol−1. With ΔG = –zFΔE, this would lower their potential by about 0.4 V. In the ion pairs, the same effect is observed, however, less pronounced with a better Cu+‐arene interaction of 5 kJ mol−1 or 0.05 V. Thus, from the observed formal potential changes ‐ with lower Cu+‐ than Ag+‐potentials in xFB for x = 1−4 ‐ one learns that the by 0.15 V higher gas phase IE Cu is overwritten by the 0.4 V higher xFB‐complexation energy of the Cu+ ion. If fully accessible, this would lead to about 0.25 V lower Cu+‐ versus Ag+‐ potentials in xFB solution. The experimental differences of 0.04 to 0.09 V in Table 2 thus suggest leveling effects on the potential, for example by ion‐pairing. Yet, the levelling effects get smaller for the least interacting solvent 5FB.

sec.title: Using the Weakly Coordinated Copper(I) Salts: Complexation Reactions with Multicyclic Arenes

caption.p: Molecular structures of the two crystallographically independent [Cu2(anthracene)2]2+ moieties in [Cu2(anthracene)2]2+([Al(ORF)4]−)2∙(6FB)1.5 7∙(6FB)1.5 (P 1¯, R 1 = 3.6%, wR 2 = 8.6%). Diagonal views on the complex on the left and top views on the complex on the right. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.

sec.p: To compare the properties of the two [Cu(2FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− and [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)}4] reagents for the application as Cu+ transfer reagents, we reacted an excess of each of these salts with hexaphenylbenzene (HPB). While the reaction with [Cu(2FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− in 2FB only affords the 2:1 adduct [(HPB){Cu(2FB)}2]2+([Al(ORF)4]−)2 8, the reaction of HPB with an excess of [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF}4] in 4FB yields the solvent‐free 3:1 adduct [Cu3(HPB)]3+([Al(ORF)4]−)3 9 (Figure 4). This indicates that the stronger solvation of the copper(I) cation in 2FB prevents the formation of a trication and thereby demonstrates the superiority of [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF}4] as a source for a “naked” Cu+.

caption.p: Molecular structures of the copper arene cations in [(HPB){Cu(2FB)}2]2+([Al(ORF)4]−)2 8 (P 1¯, R 1 = 4.8%, wR 2 = 11.9%) and [Cu3(HPB)]3+([Al(ORF)4]−)3 9 (P 1¯, R 1 = 6.5%, wR 2 = 17.6%) resulting from the reactions of HPB with [Cu(2FB)2]+[Al(ORF)4]− and [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF}4]. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this work, we presented the dinitrogen complex [(N2)Cu{Al(ORF)}4] as an accessible and very useful synthon to a solvent‐free Cu(I)‐WCA salt. It allows access to a wide range of novel, homoleptic Cu(I)‐arene complexes. Determination of the Cu+/Cu formal potentials versus Fc+/Fc revealed, particularly for the highly fluorinated systems, high to extreme potentials E°’ between 0.7 and > +1.5 V versus Fc+/Fc in xFB. These unusual values surpass those of the majority of published Cu2+/Cu+ systems and highlight the weak solvation of the Cu+ ion in these solvents and the weak Cu‐arene interactions. We anticipate widespread use of these versatile Cu(I) starting materials and the use of their formal potentials as a reference.

sec.title: Supporting Information
Author Contributions
sec.p: IK supervised and conceptionally devised the project. JW performed the DFT calculations and most of the synthetic work together with ML. The cyclic voltammetry was performed by JW and MSellin. MSellin performed the complexation reactions with multicyclic arenes together with MSeiler. The manuscript was written by JW together with IK and MSellin.

sec.title: Conflict of Interests
sec.p: The authors declare no conflict of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We would like to thank Dr. Harald Scherer for NMR measurements and discussion of spectra, Dr. Burkhard Butschke for help with scXRD structural refinement and Dr. Valentin Radtke for fruitful discussions concerning electrochemical measurements. The authors acknowledge support by the state of Baden‐Württemberg through bwHPC and the German Research Foundation (DFG) through grant no INST 40/467‐1 and 575‐1 FUGG (JUSTUS1 and 2 cluster). This work was supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation)—Project number 350173756 and through the ERC Advanced Grant InnoChem. JW is grateful for a PhD fellowship from the “Fonds der Chemischen Industrie FCI”.
Open access funding enabled and organized by Projekt DEAL.

fn.p: Note that these are predominantly structural investigations of the single crystals obtained without further investigations of the bulk materials apart from bulk analysis and mode assignment by IR and Raman spectroscopy (Supporting Information, Section 3.10).

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: Deposition Numbers 2393904 (for [Cu(C6H6)3][Al(ORF)4]), 2393903 (for [Cu(C6H6)2][Al(ORF)4]), 2393905 (for [Cu(1FB)3][Al(ORF)4]), 2407672 (for [Cu(1FB)2][Al(ORF)4], description 1), 2407673 (for [Cu(1FB)2][Al(ORF)4], description 2), 2393906 (for [Cu(3FB)2][Al(ORF)4]), 2407619 (for [(4FB)Cu{Al(ORF)4}], modification 1), 2407671 (for [(4FB)Cu{Al(ORF)4}], modification 2), 2407626 (for [Cu2(anthracene)2]2+([Al(ORF)4]−)2∙(6FB)1.5), 2407624 (for [(HPB){Cu(2FB)}2]2+([Al(ORF)4]−)2), 2407625 (for [Cu3(HPB)]3+([Al(ORF)4]−)3∙(4FB)2.5) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data are provided free of charge by the joint Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre and Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe “http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/structures” Access Structures service.
